vague_description: Determine the optimal allocation of limited resources between two process types to maximize productivity in a chemical conversion.
detailed_description: Platinum in combination with palladium has been used as a catalyst in cars and it changes carbon monoxide, which is toxic, into carbon dioxide. An automotive company is comparing two different catalysts, a palladium-heavy catalyst and a platinum-heavy catalyst. The process with a palladium-heavy catalyst requires \param{PlatinumPalladiumHeavy} units of platinum and \param{PalladiumPalladiumHeavy} units of palladium and can perform the conversion to carbon dioxide at a rate of \param{ConversionRatePalladiumHeavy} units per second. A platinum-heavy catalyst requires \param{PlatinumPlatinumHeavy} units of platinum and \param{PalladiumPlatinumHeavy} units of palladium and converts to carbon dioxide at a rate of \param{ConversionRatePlatinumHeavy} units per second. There are \param{TotalPlatinum} units of platinum and \param{TotalPalladium} units of palladium available. How many of each catalyst should be used to maximize the amount converted into carbon dioxide?
target_objective: Maximize the total amount of carbon monoxide converted into carbon dioxide
target_constraints: Platinum used for palladium-heavy catalysts is non-negative
Palladium used for palladium-heavy catalysts is non-negative
Platinum used for platinum-heavy catalysts is non-negative
Palladium used for platinum-heavy catalysts is non-negative
Total platinum used cannot exceed TotalPlatinum units
Total palladium used cannot exceed TotalPalladium units
target_parameters: Units of platinum required for palladium-heavy catalyst
Units of palladium required for palladium-heavy catalyst
Conversion rate of carbon dioxide for palladium-heavy catalyst in units per second
Units of platinum required for platinum-heavy catalyst
Units of palladium required for platinum-heavy catalyst
Conversion rate of carbon dioxide for platinum-heavy catalyst in units per second
